author: Deleted User
content: i kind of expect EIP-1559 to be implemented everywhere since it prevents all users from overpaying. Imagine what it could do if exchanges adopted it. What if it was adopted at the grocery store and online stores that sell hardware etc. no-body would overpay again

author: sky.cactus
content: It only works for selling a stream of fungible goods over time.

author: timbeiko
content: FWIW some exchanges have told us that yes, it would reduce fees, but it's just not the highest cost/benefit thing for them to support that ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

author: .vbuterin
content: IMO wallets today are making *far* too low priority fees

author: .vbuterin
content: I see wallets paying 1, 1.5, 2

author: .vbuterin
content: Every time I send, I go in manually and set it to 3-5 ü§£

author: .vbuterin
content: Given what we know empirically about people's willingness to pay for faster inclusion, rationally we should be seeing basically everyone choose a 3-5 prio fee

author: timbeiko
content: Why is that too low? I often get in within like 5 blocks with 1.5

author: timbeiko
content: If the default is 3, then you‚Äôll have to pay 5 to get in quick

author: timbeiko
content: And then 5->7, and so on, no?

author: .vbuterin
content: but I want to get in within 2 blocks, not "often within 5"!

author: .vbuterin
content: I would say not really, because it's only a few percent of the time that two blocks in a row are full

author: .vbuterin
content: I'm guessing that quite a few mining pools are setting their minimum accept rates to >1

author: .vbuterin
content: Actually, this would be a good thing to empirically research

author: .vbuterin
content: Though that requires real-time network analysis

author: timbeiko
content: But why aren‚Äôt miners including everyone at 1.5-2 ASAP then?

author: .vbuterin
content: Because the benefit/cost isn't worth it for them?

author: timbeiko
content: I wonder if maybe there isn‚Äôt some quirk in how the txn pool is sorted that explains this?

author: timbeiko
content: I‚Äôm not convinced that most miners have that level or customization of cost/benefit analysis

author: .vbuterin
content: I guess they just have a setting, and they probably set that setting to a higher number "just in case"?

author: timbeiko
content: Perhaps, yeah!

author: timbeiko
content: Because I agree with you that if there _is_ a value where they go from ‚Äúinclude soonish‚Äù to ‚Äúinclude ASAP‚Äù in the non-full blocks and our default is like 1 gwei too low, we should just change that across the board üòÑ

author: timbeiko
content: It just seems‚Ä¶ too easy?

author: .vbuterin
content: what's the harm in raising the prio fee from 1 to 2.5 by default?

author: .vbuterin
content: It's only like a couple percent of the total cost

author: timbeiko
content: Yeah, I can ask MetaMask about it!

author: timbeiko
content: Obviously not all txns go through it, but probably the best way to get data on if it makes things better or worse on aggregate üòÑ

author: chrismeislblocknative
content: fee estimation from Blocknative is specifically designed to show likelihood of getting into the next block at different confidence levels based solely on current mempool fee distribution. The estimation typically. shows 2 or higher for high confidence.  https://gas.blocknative.com

author: chrismeislblocknative
content: We can provide some statistics on how this estimation technique tracks actuals on chain if that is helpful.
